facts.text: Appeal under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 26th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 26th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature,at Bombay  Chagla C. J. and Gajendragadkar J.  in Criminal Application No. 345 of 1951.

facts.text: High Court judges: Chagla C.J. and Gajendragadkar J.

anchor.surface_text: Chagla C. J. and Gajendragadkar J.  in Criminal Application No. 345 of 1951. A. Peerbhoy, Jindra Lal and I. N. Shroff for the appellant.

facts.text: Criminal Application No. 345 of 1951 in High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Application No. 345 of 1951. A. Peerbhoy, Jindra Lal and I. N. Shroff for the appellant. K. Daphtary, Solicitor General for India  Porus A. Mehta, with them  for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by Bose J. on 1954 March 10.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. March 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bose J.-The question in this case is whether section 497 of the Indian Penal Code companytravenes articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant is being prosecuted for adultery under section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bose J.-The question in this case is whether section 497 of the Indian Penal Code companytravenes articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution. The appellant is being prosecuted for adultery under section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant applied to the High Court of Bombay under article 228 to determine constitutional question.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is being prosecuted for adultery under section 497 of the Indian Penal Code. As soon as the companyplaint was filed he applied to the High Court of Bombay to determine the companystitutional question mentioned above under article 228 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court decided against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: he applied to the High Court of Bombay to determine the companystitutional question mentioned above under article 228 of the Constitution. The High Court decided against him but granted him a certificate under articles 132  1  and 134  1   c .

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under articles 132(1) and 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided against him but granted him a certificate under articles 132  1  and 134  1   c . Under section 497 the offence of adultery can only be companymitted by a man but in the absence of any provision to the companytrary the woman would be punishable as an abettor.

facts.text: Under section 497, offence of adultery can only be committed by a man.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 497 the offence of adultery can only be companymitted by a man but in the absence of any provision to the companytrary the woman would be punishable as an abettor. The last sentence in section 497 prohibits this.

facts.text: Last sentence of section 497: In such case the wife shall not be punishable as an abettor.

anchor.surface_text: The last sentence in section 497 prohibits this. It runs- In such case the wife shall number be punishable as an abettor. It is said that this offends articles 14 and 15.

facts.text: Appellant claims section 497 offends articles 14 and 15.

anchor.surface_text: It runs- In such case the wife shall number be punishable as an abettor. It is said that this offends articles 14 and 15. The portion of article 15 on which the appellant relies is this The State shall number discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of sex.

facts.text: Article 15(3): Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women.

anchor.surface_text: The portion of article 15 on which the appellant relies is this The State shall number discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of sex. But what he overlooks is that is subject to clause  3  which runs Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women

facts.text: Appellant argued that article 15(3) should be confined to provisions beneficial to women and not to give licence to commit crimes.

anchor.surface_text: The provision companyplained of is a special provision and it is made for women, therefore it is saved by clause  3 . It was argued that clause  3  should be companyfined to provisions which are beneficial to women and cannot be used to give them a licence to companymit and abet crimes.

facts.text: Court holds appellant is not a citizen of India but High Court held otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 is general and must be read with the other provisions which set out the ambit of fundamental rights. Sex is a sound classification and although there can be numberdiscriminate in general on that ground, the Constitution itself provides for special provisions in the case of women and children. The two articles read together validate the impugned clause in section 497 of the Indian Penal Code. The appellant is number a citizen of India. It was argued that he companyld number invoke articles 14 and 15 for that reason. The High Court held otherwise.

facts.text: High Court held that appellant could invoke articles 14 and 15 despite not being citizen.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is number a citizen of India. It was argued that he companyld number invoke articles 14 and 15 for that reason. The High Court held otherwise.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: A. Peerbhoy, Jindra Lal and I. N. Shroff.

anchor.surface_text: A. Peerbhoy, Jindra Lal and I. N. Shroff for the appellant. K. Daphtary, Solicitor General for India  Porus A. Mehta, with them  for respondent No. 1. B. Dadachanji and Rajinder Narain for respondent No. 2.
